results.title: An Interview with Warwick N. Johanson
results.brief_description: After joining the Navy when he turned 17, one of the first lessons Warwick Johanson learnt was that if anything moved, you saluted it, if it stood still, you polished it. His home for over four years was aboard the flagship, the HMAS Australia, often a target for the formidable Japanese Kamakaze. Warwick also reflects on World War II and what it was like in Australia, when the country was actually in peril, almost unimaginable in this day and age.

results.title: An Interview with Harry Barkla
results.brief_description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. They were called this because it was thought that they would melt in the sun, that they wouldn’t know how to fight. In Kokoda, they soon proved themselves and Harry talks about some of the horrific experiences he went through that were typical of this war. These are some of his memories that he has tried to forget but never can. Even if you didn’t know someone’s name in the 39th Battalion, you still called them mate and you never forget your mates.

results.title: Monkey off my back
results.creator_credit: Jack Gerdsen, Ned Jeanes and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jack Gerdsen recounts his emotional return to the battleground in Korea 44 years later. He took with him soil from his backyard to honour and comfort his mates who fell there.

results.title: An Interview with Brigadier John P.A. Deighton
results.brief_description: John Deighton admits that at 18, everyone believes that they are bulletproof but the adventure of war stops when people start dying. He believes that the instant replay effect and the televisation of the Vietnam War was a factor in its unpopularity. He remembers the poor treatment Vietnam vets received on their return and how unfair it was as they were just doing their job.

results.title: An Interview with Jim Dickson
results.brief_description: Commodore Jim Dickson came from a Naval family and joined the cadets at 13. As a ship navigator off the coast of Vietnam in 1965, he experienced the pressure of being responsible for the welfare of the crew and the ship. He reflects on the turbulence of the era, the bonds that are formed in times of adversity and the terrible waste wrought by war.
results.description: Commodore Jim Dickson came from a Naval family and joined the cadets at 13. He reflects on the turbulence of the era, the bonds that are formed in times of adversity and the terrible waste wrought by war.

results.title: An Interview with Major General Jim Hughes
results.brief_description: Major General Jim Hughes joined the army just after World War II. Army life suited him and he served as a platoon commander in Korea in the 1950s. He details one particularly long Sunday, during this time, when his company was ambushed by the Chinese and resulted in him maturing considerably in one day.

results.title: An Interview with Pat Vines
results.creator_credit: Pat Vines and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Pat Vines joined the Australian Navy as a nurse during World War II. She moved up the ranks and eventually became a Commander. Pat tells her story through her memories of wartime and what it was like to work in the Navy.
results.description: Pat Vines joined the Australian Navy as a nurse during World War II. She moved up the ranks and eventually became a Commander. Pat tells her story through her memories of wartime and what it was like to work in the Navy.

results.title: An Interview with Pat Vines: The Shrine of Remembrance
results.creator_credit: Pat Vines and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After Pat Vines returns from the war as a Commander of the Australian Navy, one of her senior navy officers recommends her to the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees, which she joins. She tells of her time as a Trustee for the Shrine.

results.title: Who Gives a Stuff About the Farmer
results.creator_credit: Simon Walshe, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: This provocative short documentary combines a song written by JR Williams about the plight of the dairy farmer with images of farmers at work in the Gunbower region. JR was inspired to write this song in response to the pipeline development that is set to take water from the Campaspe area to Melbourne. The song is to inform people, especially those living in the city that farmers are doing it tough and that taking water away from regional towns is not a sustainable solution for the city’s water shortage.
results.title_for_label: Who Gives a Stuff About the Farmer
results.description: This provocative short documentary combines a song written by JR Williams about the plight of the dairy farmer with images of farmers at work in the Gunbower region. JR was inspired to write this song in response to the pipeline development that is set to take water from the Campaspe area to Melbourne. The song is to inform people, especially those living in the city that farmers are doing it tough and that taking water away from regional towns is not a sustainable solution for the city’s water shortage.

results.title: The Whistling Eagle
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: The story of The Whistling Eagle winery is one of love: for wine, family and for each other. Ian and Lynn Rathjen were the first couple to plant grape vines in the Colbinabbin area and present a very open and honest interview, giving insights into their lives together before and since starting the winery.
